trans-unit.source: Deploying Your Own Private Docker Registry on Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploying Your Own Private Docker Registry on Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how you can use Docker Registry to host your container images on the Azure Blob Storage service.
trans-unit.target: Describes how you can use Docker Registry to host your container images on the Azure Blob Storage service.

trans-unit.source: This document describes what a Docker private registry is and shows how you can deploy a Docker Registry 2.0 container image to a Docker private registry on Microsoft Azure using Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: This document describes what a Docker private registry is and shows how you can deploy a Docker Registry 2.0 container image to a Docker private registry on Microsoft Azure using Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: This document assumes:
trans-unit.target: This document assumes:

trans-unit.source: You know how to use Docker and have Docker images to store.
trans-unit.target: You know how to use Docker and have Docker images to store.

trans-unit.source: (You don't?
trans-unit.target: (You don't?

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Learn about Docker</linkText><title></title>)
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Learn about Docker</linkText><title></title>)

trans-unit.source: You have a server that has Docker engine installed.
trans-unit.target: You have a server that has Docker engine installed.

trans-unit.source: (You don't?
trans-unit.target: (You don't?

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Do it quickly on Azure.</linkText><title></title>)
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Do it quickly on Azure.</linkText><title></title>)

trans-unit.source: In order to ship your containerized applications to the cloud, you construct a Docker container image and store it somewhere so that it can be used by yourself and by others.
trans-unit.target: In order to ship your containerized applications to the cloud, you construct a Docker container image and store it somewhere so that it can be used by yourself and by others.

trans-unit.source: While creating a container image and shipping it to the cloud is easy, it is a challenge to store the generated image reliably.
trans-unit.target: While creating a container image and shipping it to the cloud is easy, it is a challenge to store the generated image reliably.

trans-unit.source: For that reason, Docker offers a centralized service called <linkText>Docker Hub[docker-hub]</linkText><title></title> to store container images on the cloud and allows you to create containers anytime using those images.
trans-unit.target: For that reason, Docker offers a centralized service called <linkText>Docker Hub[docker-hub]</linkText><title></title> to store container images on the cloud and allows you to create containers anytime using those images.

trans-unit.source: Although the <linkText>Docker Hub[docker-hub]</linkText><title></title> is a paid service for storing your private application container images, Docker respects developers’ needs and provides an open-source toolset to store your images in your own private Docker registry behind a firewall or on-premises without hitting the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: Although the <linkText>Docker Hub[docker-hub]</linkText><title></title> is a paid service for storing your private application container images, Docker respects developers’ needs and provides an open-source toolset to store your images in your own private Docker registry behind a firewall or on-premises without hitting the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: Because Azure Blob storage is easy to secure, you can quickly use it to create and use a private Docker registry in Azure that you control yourself.
trans-unit.target: Because Azure Blob storage is easy to secure, you can quickly use it to create and use a private Docker registry in Azure that you control yourself.

trans-unit.source: By hosting your Docker Registry instance on Microsoft Azure and storing your images on Azure Blob Storage, you can have several benefits:
trans-unit.target: By hosting your Docker Registry instance on Microsoft Azure and storing your images on Azure Blob Storage, you can have several benefits:

trans-unit.source: Security: Your Docker images do not leave Azure datacenters, so they do not cross the public Internet as they would if you were using Docker Hub.
trans-unit.target: Security: Your Docker images do not leave Azure datacenters, so they do not cross the public Internet as they would if you were using Docker Hub.

trans-unit.source: Performance: Your Docker images are stored are stored within the same datacenter or region as your applications.
trans-unit.target: Performance: Your Docker images are stored are stored within the same datacenter or region as your applications.

trans-unit.source: This means the images will be pulled faster and more reliably compared to Docker Hub.
trans-unit.target: This means the images will be pulled faster and more reliably compared to Docker Hub.

trans-unit.source: Reliability: By using Microsoft Azure Blob Storage, you can make use of many storage properties like high availability, redundancy, premium storage (SSDs), and so on.
trans-unit.target: Reliability: By using Microsoft Azure Blob Storage, you can make use of many storage properties like high availability, redundancy, premium storage (SSDs), and so on.

trans-unit.source: (It's recommended to read the <linkText>Docker Registry 2.0 documentation[registry-docs]</linkText><title></title> before proceeding.)
trans-unit.target: (It's recommended to read the <linkText>Docker Registry 2.0 documentation[registry-docs]</linkText><title></title> before proceeding.)

trans-unit.source: You can <linkText>configure[registry-config]</linkText><title></title> your Docker Registry in two different ways.
trans-unit.target: You can <linkText>configure[registry-config]</linkText><title></title> your Docker Registry in two different ways.

trans-unit.source: You can:
trans-unit.target: You can:

trans-unit.source: Use a config.yml file.
trans-unit.target: Use a config.yml file.

trans-unit.source: In this case you will need to create a separate Docker image on top of registry image.
trans-unit.target: In this case you will need to create a separate Docker image on top of registry image.

trans-unit.source: Override the default configuration file through environment variables: gets things done without creating and maintaining a separate Docker image.
trans-unit.target: Override the default configuration file through environment variables: gets things done without creating and maintaining a separate Docker image.

trans-unit.source: For the sake of simplicity, this topic follows option 2, using the environment variables.
trans-unit.target: For the sake of simplicity, this topic follows option 2, using the environment variables.

trans-unit.source: In order to run a Docker Registry instance which:
trans-unit.target: In order to run a Docker Registry instance which:

trans-unit.source: uses your Azure Storage Account for storing the images
trans-unit.target: uses your Azure Storage Account for storing the images

trans-unit.source: listens on the Virtual Machine's port 5000
trans-unit.target: listens on the Virtual Machine's port 5000

trans-unit.source: has no authentication configured (not recommended, see the note below)
trans-unit.target: has no authentication configured (not recommended, see the note below)

trans-unit.source: you need to run the following Docker command in your bash terminal (replace and with your credentials):
trans-unit.target: you need to run the following Docker command in your bash terminal (replace and with your credentials):

trans-unit.source: Once the command exits, you can see the container hosting your private Docker Registry instance by running the docker ps command on your host:
trans-unit.target: Once the command exits, you can see the container hosting your private Docker Registry instance by running the docker ps command on your host:

trans-unit.source: Configuring security for the Docker Registry is not covered in this document and your registry will be accessible to anyone without authentication by default if you open up the port to the registry port on the Virtual Machine endpoint or load balancer if you use the deployment command above.
trans-unit.target: Configuring security for the Docker Registry is not covered in this document and your registry will be accessible to anyone without authentication by default if you open up the port to the registry port on the Virtual Machine endpoint or load balancer if you use the deployment command above.

trans-unit.source: Please read the <linkText>Configuring Docker Registry[registry-config]</linkText><title></title> documentation to learn how to secure the registry instance and your images.
trans-unit.target: Please read the <linkText>Configuring Docker Registry[registry-config]</linkText><title></title> documentation to learn how to secure the registry instance and your images.

trans-unit.source: Once you have your registry set up, it's time to go use it some more.
trans-unit.target: Once you have your registry set up, it's time to go use it some more.

trans-unit.source: Start with the docker [registry-docs].
trans-unit.target: Start with the docker [registry-docs].
